00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 parserVectorUtils.pl - Utility macros that are useful in vector problems.
00020 
00021 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00022 
00023 Some utility routines that are useful in vector problems
00024 
00025 =cut
00026 
00027 sub _parserVectorUtils_init {}; # don't reload this file
00028 
00029 =head1 MACROS
00030 
00031 =head2 Overline
00032 
00033     Overline($vectorName)
00034 
00035 formats a vector name (should be used in math mode)
00036 
00037 Vectors will be in bold italics in HTML modes, and
00038 will be overlined in TeX modes.  (Bold italic could also work in
00039 TeX modes, but the low resolution on screen made it less easy
00040 to distinguish the difference between bold and regular letters.)
00041 
00042 =cut
00043 
00044 sub Overline {
00045   my $v = shift;
00046   my $HTML = '<B><I>'.$v.'</B></I>';
00047   MODES(
00048     TeX => "\\overline{$v}",
00049     HTML => $HTML,
00050     HTML_tth => '\begin{rawhtml}'.$HTML.'\end{rawhtml}',
00051     HTML_dpng => "\\overline{$v}",
00052   );
00053 }
00054 
00055 =head2 BoldMath
00056 
00057     BoldMath($vectorName)
00058 
00059 This gets a bold letter in TeX as well as HTML modes.
00060 Although \boldsymbol{} works fine on screen in latex2html mode,
00061 the PDF file produces non-bold letters.  I haven't been able to
00062 track this down, so used \mathbf{} in TeX mode, which produces
00063 roman bold, not math-italic bold.
00064 
00065 =cut
00066 
00067 sub BoldMath {
00068   my $v = shift;
00069   my $HTML = '<B><I>'.$v.'</B></I>';
00070   MODES(
00071     TeX => "\\boldsymbol{$v}", #  doesn't seem to work in TeX mode
00072 #    TeX => "\\mathbf{$v}",      #  gives non-italic bold in TeX mode
00073     Latex2HTML => "\\boldsymbol{$v}",
00074     HTML => $HTML,
00075     HTML_tth => '\begin{rawhtml}'.$HTML.'\end{rawhtml}',
00076     HTML_dpng => "\\boldsymbol{$v}",
00077   );
00078 }
00079 
00080 =head2 $GRAD
00081 
00082     TEXT($GRAD)
00083 
00084     BEGIN_TEXT
00085     $GRAD
00086     END_TEXT
00087 
00088 Grad symbol.
00089 
00090 =cut
00091 
00092 $GRAD = '\nabla ';
00093 
00094 =head2 non_zero_point
00095 
00096     non_zero_point($Dim,$L_bound,$U_bound,$step)
00097 
00098 Create a non-zero point with the given number of coordinates
00099 with the given random range (which defaults to (-5,5,1)).
00100 
00101 non_zero_point(n,a,b,c)
00102 non_zero_point_2D(a,b,c)
00103 non_zero_point_3D(a,b,c)
00104 
00105 non_zero_point2D and 3D automatically set Dimension to 2 and 3 respectively.
00106 
00107 =cut
00108 
00109 sub non_zero_point {
00110   my $n = shift; my $k = $n; my @v = ();
00111   my $a = shift || -5; my $b = shift || $a + 10; my $c = shift || 1;
00112   while ($k--) {push(@v,random($a,$b,$c))}
00113   if (norm(Point(@v)) == 0) {$v[random(0,$n-1,1)] = non_zero_random($a,$b,$c)}
00114   return Point(@v);
00115 }
00116 sub non_zero_point2D {non_zero_point(2,@_)}
00117 sub non_zero_point3D {non_zero_point(3,@_)}
00118 
00119 =head2 non_zero_vector, non_zero_vector2D, non_zero_vector3D
00120 
00121     non_zero_vector($Dim,$L_bound,$U_bound,$step)
00122 
00123     non_zero_vector2D($L_bound,$U_bound,$step)
00124 
00125     non_zero_vector3D($L_bound,$U_bound,$step)
00126 
00127 Functions the same as non_zero_point but for Vectors. non_zero_vector2D and
00128 non_zero_vector3D automatically set Dimension to 2 and 3 respectively.
00129 
00130 =cut
00131 
00132 sub non_zero_vector   {Vector(non_zero_point(@_))}
00133 sub non_zero_vector2D {non_zero_vector(2,@_)}
00134 sub non_zero_vector3D {non_zero_vector(3,@_)}
00135 
00136 =head2 Line
00137 
00138     $P = Point(@coords1);
00139     $V = Vector(@coords2);
00140     $t = 't';
00141     Line($P,$V);
00142     Line($P,$V,$t);
00143 
00144 Form the vector-parametric form for a line given its point and vector, where $P
00145 is the point and $V the direction vector for the line, and $t is the variable to
00146 use (default is 't').
00147 
00148 For example:
00149 
00150     Line([1,-3],[2,1]);            # produces Vector("1+2t","-3+t").
00151     Line(Point(1,-3),Vector(2,1)); # produces Vector("1+2t","-3+t").
00152 
00153 (It may be better to use the ParametricLine class from
00154 parserParametricLine.pl).
00155 
00156 =cut
00157 
00158 sub Line {
00159   my @p = Point(shift)->value; my @v = Vector(shift)->value;
00160   my $t = shift; $t = 't' unless $t; $t = Formula($t);
00161   my @coords = ();
00162   die "Dimensions of point and vector don't match" unless $#p == $#v;
00163   foreach my $i (0..$#p) {push(@coords,($p[$i]+$v[$i]*$t)->reduce)}
00164   return Vector(@coords);
00165 }
00166 
00167 =head2 Plane
00168 
00169     Plane($point,$NormalVector)
00170 
00171 Creates a displayable string for a plane given its
00172 normal vector and a point on the plane.  (Better to use
00173 the ImplicitPlane class from parserImplicitPlane.pl).
00174 
00175 =cut
00176 
00177 sub Plane {
00178   my $P = Point(shift); my $N = Vector(shift); my @N = $N->value;
00179   my $xyz = shift; $xyz = ['x','y','z'] unless defined($xyz);
00180   die "Number of variables doesn't match dimension of normal vector"
00181     unless scalar(@N) == scalar(@{$xyz});
00182   my @terms = ();
00183   foreach my $i (0..$#N) {push(@terms,$N[$i]->TeX.$xyz->[$i])}
00184   Formula(join(' + ',@terms))->reduce->TeX . " = " . ($N.$P)->TeX;
00185 }
